61 years ago the harvard business school
class of
1949 graduated from this university
and started their careers at the dawn of
a great period of post-war economic
prosperity
the class went on to become widely
regarded as one of the most successful
classes
in the school's history 28 retired as
ceo or president of their company
and at one time included the ceos of
bloomingdale's
johnson johnson and xerox among the
ranks
over the years the class has been the
topic of numerous books and studies
including a comprehensive survey

richard tedlow
the researchers distinguished between
two very different types of business
success
the first is what we're all familiar
with achieving a top leadership position
and being rewarded with the trappings of
wealth status and power
the class of 1949 was certainly
successful in that regard
perhaps surprisingly however it was a
second type of success
that truly differentiated this class

and after it to achieve the second type
of success
the graduates had to navigate three
conflicts that will certainly

finding work
they enjoyed versus making money at a

the second was holding on to the love of

commitment to their careers
the third involved balancing the

the ability to advance their careers
